abstract: The photographer Noah Abrams documents a small but thriving skateboarding scene in war-torn Afghanistan.
snippet: The photographer Noah Abrams documents a small but thriving skateboarding scene in war-torn Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2008, the photographer Noah Abrams came across a YouTube clip of a couple of Afghan kids skateboarding in Kabul. "It struck me as the most positive image I'd seen in a long time," he says. "I had to figure out a way to get over there." Abrams, a skater himself, made two trips the following year to photograph what turned out to be a small but thriving skating scene in the war-torn city, in part the work of Skateistan, a school started in 2007 by two Australian skaters. (A documentary film about the program, "Skateistan: To Live and Skate Kabul," had its premiere at Sundance this year.) Overcoming a lack of smooth roads and sidewalks, among other things, Kabul's skaters - girls included - find in skating a rare recreational outlet, Abrams says. "The mullahs have no problem with girls skating. They can't ride a bike, but they can skate. The girls just jump on it."
